Andrea Pires dos Santos

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/4042561743014784
  • Última atualização do currículo em 10/06/2019

Possui graduação em Medicina Veterinária pela Universidade Federal de Santa Maria (2001), mestrado em Clínica Médica Veterinária pela Universidade Federal de Santa Maria (2004) e doutorado em Patologia Clínica Veterinária na Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul (2008) com parte no exterior na Universidade de Purdue (Lafayette, IN, EUA). Realizou pós-doutorado na Universidade de Purdue (2008-2014). Possui residência em patologia clínica Veterinária na Universidade de Purdue (EUA). Diplomada pela associacao americana de patologia clinica veterinaria (ASVCP) (2018). Tem experiência na área de Medicina Veterinária, com ênfase em patologia clínica veterinária e biologia molecular, atuando principalmente nos seguintes temas: hematologia, bioquímica clínica, hemostasia e biologia molecular com linhas de pesquisa em doenças infecciosas, câncer e microRNA. Atualmente é professora de patologia clínica veterinária na Universidade de Purdue (2017). (Texto informado pelo autor)

Projetos de pesquisa
2018 - Atual
Análise comparativa da expressão de miRNAs de macrófagos humano, bovino e murino infectados com bactérias do Complexo Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
Descrição: O presente projeto visa comparar a expressão de miRNAs de macrófagos humanos, murinos e bovinos infectados com diferentes espécies do MTC (Mtb, M. africanum L1, M. africanum L2, M. bovis e M. caprae) e M. canetti, utilizando tecnologia de sequenciamento de nova geração (miRNA-Seq)..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Mestrado acadêmico: (1) .

Integrantes: Andrea Pires dos Santos - Integrante / Guimaraes, A.M.S. - Coordenador / Kerstin Muner - Integrante.
2018 - Atual
Análise comparativa da expressão de miRNAs de macrófagos humano, bovino e murino infectados com bactérias do Complexo Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
Descrição: Este projeto visa comparar a expressão de miRNAs de macrófagos humanos, murinos e bovinos infectados com diferentes espécies do MTC (Mtb, M. africanum L1, M. africanum L2, M. bovis e M. caprae) e M. canetti, utilizando tecnologia de sequenciamento de nova geração (miRNA-Seq)..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Andrea Pires dos Santos - Integrante / Guimaraes, A.M.S. - Coordenador / Kerstin Muner - Integrante.
2017 - Atual
Detection of Phytium sp. in granulomatous inflammation lesions by a pan-fungal PCR from FFPE tissue.
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Andrea Pires dos Santos - Integrante / Nelly O. Elshafie - Integrante / Lynn F. Guptill - Coordenador / Yava Jones - Integrante.

Reactive oxygen species production and biomarkers of oxidative stress in anemic dogs

2017 - Atual
MicroRNA Biomarkers in Canine Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma Diagnosis, Prognosis, and Therapeutic Outcome.
Descrição: This project aims to identify miRNA expression profiles (miRNA ?signatures?) in canine DLBCL as potential diagnostic and prognostic biomarkers of disease..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (1) / Doutorado: (1) .

Integrantes: Andrea Pires dos Santos - Coordenador / Phillip SanMiguel - Integrante / Nelly O. Elshafie - Integrante / Michael O. Childress - Integrante / Andrea L. Kasinski - Integrante / Audrey Ruple - Integrante / Sagar M. Utturkar - Integrante.
2017 - Atual
Differential microRNA expression profiles in dogs with transitional cell carcinoma
Descrição: Our aim is to identify the differentially expressed miRNAs in FFPE tissue from TCC and adjacent normal tissue from dogs presented to the Purdue University Veterinary Teaching Hospital. Our hypothesis is that, as seen in humans, miRNAs are differentially expressed in the tumor tissue compared to adjacent normal tissue. We will use high-throughput genome-wide analysis (next generation sequencing, Illumina) to examine the full spectrum of miRNAs expressed in TCC tissue compared to normal adjacent tissue..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (2) .

Integrantes: Andrea Pires dos Santos - Coordenador / Pierre L. Deshuillers - Integrante / Deborah W. Knapp - Integrante / Jose Ramos-Vara - Integrante / Nelly O. Elshafie - Integrante / Caitlyn J. Ridenour - Integrante.
2017 - Atual
Comparative study of host-pathogen interactions of Mycobacterium bovis and Mycobacterium tuberculosis during infection of human macrophages using RNA sequencing.
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Andrea Pires dos Santos - Integrante / Guimaraes, A.M.S. - Coordenador.
2016 - Atual
Bio-engineered probiotics to control Listeria monocytogenes infection in a mouse model
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Andrea Pires dos Santos - Integrante / A. K. Bhunia - Coordenador.
2015 - Atual
Evaluation of anti-oxidant pathway related micro RNA in cat erythrocytes in health and disease: could they be used as biomarkers of systemic oxidative stress?
Descrição: The goal of this study is to evaluate the role of miR-451/144 and other micro RNAs in the decreased antioxidant capacity of cats and assess potential changes during diabetes mellitus. This study also provides preliminary data for the evaluation of these micro RNAs as biomarker of systemic oxidative stress and evaluation of the associated antioxidant response. A long term goal is to decipher the antioxidant pathway in the erythroid lineage and its relationship to systemic oxidative stress, antioxidant defense and the development of feline diseases such as diabetes..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Doutorado: (1) .

Integrantes: Andrea Pires dos Santos - Integrante / Joanne Belle Messick - Coordenador / Phillip SanMiguel - Integrante / Pierre L. Deshuillers - Integrante / Lynn F. Guptill - Integrante / Jyothi Thimmapuram - Integrante.
2015 - Atual
Evaluation of anti-oxidant pathway related micro RNA in cat erythrocytes in health and disease
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Doutorado: (1) .

Integrantes: Andrea Pires dos Santos - Integrante / Messick, J.B. - Coordenador / Pierre L. Deshuillers - Integrante.
2010 - 2013
Genome-wide Analysis of Mycoplasma haemofelis Pathogenesis, Evolution and Metabolism
Descrição: Descrição: About 25% of all cats that are anemic and/or acutely ill have a M. haemofelis infection. In cats, this parasite has been widely studied due to its role as a primary pathogen, cofactor in the pathogenesis of retroviral and other diseases, and its propensity to establish chronic infections despite antibiotic treatment. There is molecular evidence suggesting that M. haemofelis and its relatives (formerly Haemobartonella and Eperythrozoon) define a new clad of mycoplasmas, which unlike other mycoplasmas, have a unique tropism for the red blood cell of their vertebrate host. These parasites, given the trivial name hemoplasmas, are most closely related to members of the M. pneumoniae group. Our laboratory group recently successfully sequenced and have a draft assembly of the entire genome of M. haemofelis. A long-term goal for sequencing M. haemofelis is to identify genes involved in virulence and survival, helping to pave the way for diagnostic testing, vaccine development and treatment strategies. The overall objectives of our proposal are to annotate and analyze the genomic sequence of M. haemofelis, to understand how it causes disease and provide new insights into the evolution of these hemoplasmas. Furthermore, information about the biochemical pathways used by M. haemofelis will provide valuable clues about culture conditions needed to support hemoplasma growth in vitro, which to date has not been achieved. We look forward to never infecting another cat to harvest parasites for experimental studies. It is anticipated that the findings of these studies will dramatically alter our understanding of M. haemofelis. ..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Andrea Pires dos Santos - Coordenador / Joanne Belle Messick - Integrante / Ana Marcia Guimaraes - Integrante / Phillip San Miguel - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Morris Animal Foundation - Auxílio financeiro.
2010 - 2012
Expressional immunoreactive antigens of Mycoplasma suis and development of an immunoassay.
Descrição: The acute eperythrozoonosis has an adverse economic impact on commercial swine herds; however, the consequences of the chronic disease are still unkown due to the absence of sensitive diagnostic tests. The observation of the parasite on stained blood smears identifies only few animals in the acute phase of the disease and can result in false positives because of staining artifacts. Nowadays, PCR is the most commonly used diagnostic test for hemoplasma infection. This technique accurately detects acutely ill pigs and those with relapsing illness; however, we have recently demonstrated that it also fails to identify significant numbers of chronically infected animals (GUIMARAES et al., 2007). In addition, the PCR assay requires specialized equipment and highly trained personnel; making difficult to establish it in a herd diagnostic routine. Serological tests are preferred because of the improved sensitivity and reproducibility; however, assays already developed have not gained wide acceptance, largely because the source of antigen is not readily available. Since hemoplasmas do not grow in vitro, developing of a serological test with a reliable and renewable source of antigen includes the detection of genes coding for immunoreactive antigens, cloning them into expression vectors, and recovering immunoreactive proteins. Using molecular techniques it will be possible to produce large quantities of M. suis recombinant antigens. This would be a source of M. suis antigens that is convenient, renewable, and once purified, can be standardized for use in a immunoassay using the Luminex technology. Furthermore, a M. suis genomic library associated to its genes evaluation and development of recombinant antigens may provide crucial information about M. suis pathogenicity and vaccine potential..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Andrea Pires dos Santos - Integrante / Joanne Belle Messick - Integrante / Ana Marcia Guimaraes - Coordenador.
2010 - 2012
Sequencing and annotation of the Mycoplasma suis genome
Descrição: Mycoplasma suis is the causative agent of eperythrozoonosis in domestic and wild pigs. Although sufficient information is available to describe the clinical significance of this pathogen to the swine medicine, host-pathogen interactions, transmission, virulence and survival factors are virtually unknown. In addition, genes that are unique to hemoplasmas, giving them the ability to parasitize red blood cells, haven't been described. This study aim to use a whole genome sequencing and analysis approach to determine the M. suis virulence and pathogenicity mechanisms as well as biochemical pathways that may lead to its further cultivation in vitro..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Andrea Pires dos Santos - Integrante / Joanne Belle Messick - Integrante / Ana Marcia Guimaraes - Coordenador / Phillip San Miguel - Integrante.
2008 - 2010
Immunoreactive antigens of Mycoplasma haemofelis and development of an Immunoassay.
Descrição: Mycoplasma haemofelis infection frequently causes anemia in cats that can be life threatening. The use of appropriate antibiotics can prevent death, however the parasites are not completely cleared. Even PCR testing may miss cats with these chronic infections. Our hypothesis is that detection of antibodies to M. haemofelis is a more sensitive approach to identify infected cats. To date, no immunoassay has been developed. This is because M. haemofelis cannot be grown in culture and infecting a cat to harvest organisms to be used as a crude source of antigen for antibody-based testing is a poor alternative. The objective of our work was to identify and provide a convenient and renewable source of antigen for use in an immunoassay and/or for vaccine production. To achieve this objective, the following stepwise molecular approach is planned: 1) identify clones in an expression library of M. haemofelis that are recognized by feline antibodies directed against the parasite; 2) characterize gene inserts within clones that react with specific antibody; 3) clone and recover several recombinant antigens (immunogens); 4) simultaneously investigate the diagnostic relevance of recombinant immunogens using a Luminex® system. This immunoassay in conjunction with the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test that our laboratory previously developed, will provide us with the necessary tools to better understand the impact of M. haemofelis infections on the health and well being of cats. The test might also lead to the implementation of new control strategies, and monies generated from a patent on this test could be used for feline related research. Finally, the antigens we identify might also be valuable sites to target for development of a vaccine to control or thwart the infection of cats..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Andrea Pires dos Santos - Coordenador / Andreea Pires dos Santos - Integrante / Joanne Belle Messick - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Morris Animal Foundation - Auxílio financeiro.
